Class commonCanvas

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Canvas

All Implemented Interfaces:

Direct Known Subclasses:
CannonViewer, CheckerGameViewer, CheViewer, DipoleGameViewer, DvonnViewer, ExxitGameViewer, FanoronaGameViewer, FourViewer, GipfViewer, GobGameViewer, HexGameViewer, HiveGameViewer, KnockaboutViewer, KubaViewer, LoaViewer, MedinaViewer, MicropulViewer, PalagoViewer, PlateauGameViewer, PunctGameViewer, QyshinsuViewer, SantoriniViewer, SpanglesViewer, TabGameViewer, TraxGameViewer, TruGameViewer, TumbleGameViewer, TzaarViewer, VolcanoGameViewer, Warp6Viewer, YinshGameViewer, ZertzGameViewer
public abstract class commonCanvas
extends exCanvas
implements ViewerProtocol, sgf_names

This class extends Canvas and provides a bunch of services for the individual game's Viewer class. The main services are a history of moves in the game a "VCR cluster" of forward-back controls to view the game history. mouse handling repaint management some standard option menus debugging aids for screen layout and performance run loop

See Also:

Method Detail

midGamePoint

public int midGamePoint()
Description copied from interface: ViewerProtocol
the number of moves at which midgame is reached, this is just a guess, not a contract. When this point in the game is reached, a midpoint digest is extracted for later use in fraud detection. midGamePoint() only relevant the first time MoveStep() is greater, so a variety of strategies for determining and declaring midpoint could be used.

Specified by:
midGamePoint in interface ViewerProtocol

MoveStep

public int MoveStep()
return the current real move number. This is used by the game controller to tell when to ask for the mid game digest (at 20 moves) and when to consider a game a game to be recorded (after 3 moves).

Specified by:
MoveStep in interface ViewGameProtocol

Digest

public int Digest()
this provides the game state, digested as a unique integer, for the game controller for fraud detection (the fraud being to play the same game over and over to inflate your score). It's used at midgame as well as endgame, to uniquely identify this game.

Specified by:
Digest in interface ViewerProtocol

addNewSpectator

public void addNewSpectator(commonPlayer p,
                            commonPlayer replace)
Description copied from interface: ViewGameProtocol
add a new spectator to the list of commonPlayers, replace the one specified, which may be null, meaning assign the next empty slot. If both are null clear the player list. This is used by the Game to keep the Viewer informed of the identities of the Spectators. In review rooms, there are only spectators.

Specified by:
addNewSpectator in interface ViewGameProtocol
Parameters:
p - the player to add, or null to remove
replace - the player to replace, or null to assign a new slot.

doMouseTracking

public void doMouseTracking(commonPlayer player,
                            int inx,
                            int iny,
                            java.lang.String onoff,
                            int ino)
Description copied from interface: ViewGameProtocol
Record the latest mouse tracking infomation about the player (or spectator). only remembering, no other action, should occur. By convention, record nothing if player happens to be self. Also by convention, if ino is >=0 it reflects an object begin moved by the player, and all the other players should be set to not be moving. By convention, there is at most one moving object in the game at any time.

Specified by:
doMouseTracking in interface ViewGameProtocol
Parameters:
player - the player, or spectator.
inx - encoded x coordinate
iny - encoded y coordinate
onoff - on if the mouse if being tracked on the canvas
ino - if >=0 represents an object being moved.

UndoStep

public void UndoStep()
move the view of the game history back one step. The default inplementation does this the simplest and dumbest way, by calling "doWayBack()" and then stepping forward. For most circumstances this should be fine. You can override this method with a fancier or smarter UNDO if needed.

doWayBack

public void doWayBack()
move the view of the game history all the way back to the beginning. This could be implemented cleverly, but the simple and reliable method is to just reinialize the board.

doInit

public void doInit(boolean preserve_history)
Description copied from interface: ViewerProtocol
initialize back to the "start" position. This is used when a reviewer is about to load a new game, or when the "WayBack" button is pressed. In particular, this implies that the players list (and maybe also the game subtype) may change. As invoked by the game controller, "preserve_history" will always be false, indicating that history should be discarded.

Specified by:
doInit in interface ViewerProtocol

formHistoryString

public void formHistoryString(java.io.PrintWriter os)

formStoryString

public java.lang.String formStoryString()
Description copied from interface: ViewGameProtocol
return a history string which will allow another viewer (as player or spectator) to replay the game. This is used to get new spectators up to date with the state of the game. This string should be as brief as possible to minimize bandwidth, and should grow by adding new stuff to the end, so only the end of the string needs to be transmitted. The defaullt method uses the move history to generate a printable/parseable representation of the game.

Specified by:
formStoryString in interface ViewGameProtocol

formEphemeralHistoryString

public java.lang.String formEphemeralHistoryString()
Description copied from interface: ViewGameProtocol
return a short string reflecting any ephmeral (rapidly changing) state of the game, for example the next player to play. You can alter the default method if you make corresponding adjustments in the useEphemeralBuffer method. Recommended practice is to tack a parseable preamble onto the standard string.

Specified by:
formEphemeralHistoryString in interface ViewGameProtocol

ReplayGame

public void ReplayGame(sgf_game ga)
replayGame replays a SGF record structure. This is the normal route for game reviewers get games.

save_game

public sgf_game save_game()
save the game as a sgf record structure, which will be printed to a file. This path is actually not much used, since we don't usually output files directly.

printGameRecord

public void printGameRecord(java.io.PrintWriter ps,
                            java.lang.String startingTime,
                            java.util.Vector his)
print the game record directly from the history. This is the way games are recorded by the server: printed by this printwriter into a string, which is transmitted to the server over the net connection, and the server writes the file. The net effect should be very similar to the SGF output.

Description copied from interface: ViewGameProtocol
print the game record as a SGF file. These are "public" rather than private formats, but mainly to be parsed by the reviewer version of the viewer.

Specified by:
printGameRecord in interface ViewGameProtocol

ViewerRun

public void ViewerRun()
Description copied from interface: CanvasProtocol
do any pending tasks (on a time scale of fractions of a second). This will normally include such tasks as redrawing the window, processing mouse gestures, and handling incoming moves. Note that most realtime events just record their state and exit, leaving this process to actually do the work. Using a single process in this way avoids race conditions and deadlocks. This loop automatically traps errors and reports them, which is the primary mechansism to get feedback about bugs in the game implementation

Specified by:
ViewerRun in interface CanvasProtocol
Overrides:
ViewerRun in class exCanvas

getBoardCoords

public java.awt.Point getBoardCoords(int x,
                                     int y)
translate the mouse coordinate x,y into a size-independent representation presumably based on the cell grid. This is used to transmit our mouse position to the other players and spectators, so it will be displayed at approximately the same visual spot on their screen.

Specified by:

useStoryBuffer

public void useStoryBuffer(java.lang.String tok,
                           java.util.StringTokenizer his)
Description copied from interface: ViewGameProtocol
interpret a history string as created by formHistoryString. The contract is to bring the local game into the same state as the game that created the string. This is used to give spectators the view of the game, and also to reconnect players that have been disconnected.

Specified by:

Specified by:

verifyGameRecord

public void verifyGameRecord()
verify the game record is still correct by cloning the board and replaying it. This is intended to catch "editing errors" by editHistory, but may also catch cases where Digest() is not producing the same result. In the process this exercises a lot of the game machinery, so other latent bugs are likely to show up right away as errors thrown from verifyGameRecord
